quote: We will proceed according to the traditions and precedents set down in Klingon law.
What do you know of Klingon law, Human?
We will reconvene on the Enterprise within---
No! Finish it here, now!
I... have not received your report on the explosion.
Two Klingons killed... a few minor injuries. Were you concerned about me?
As head of security... it is my duty to be concerned.
Is that it? Just official concern for my well-being?
You know my... feelings.
Maybe I've forgotten.
You were right... I would have insisted that we take the oath. But not just because of tradition...
I thought about telling you... wanted to tell you. I wasn't ready.
When I left, you said you'd never be complete without me. It took some time... but I came to realize... I need you too. You're part of me, Worf.
jIH dok
maj dok
I cannot allow you to... suffer my humiliation.
There would be no suffering... I don't care what other Klingons think of you.
But what of the boy? He may want to live in the Empire someday. He would be an outcast... another traitor from a family of traitors.
"Family of traitors?" I don't believe that for a minute.
Respect my wishes in this matter. I cannot take the oath with you... And I cannot claim your son.
If you cannot be his father... at least be his friend.
We haven't completed our analysis of the bomb debris... and Doctor Crusher is still studying the remains of the two men killed in the explosion. We need more time.
Duras and Gowron will be here in a few minutes. I don't think you can delay this meeting again.
Is there some way of stretching out the formalities once they arrive?
In the modern Rite of Succession, only a brief proclamation that two challengers have been chosen is necessary.
You said "modern Rite"... how was the ritual performed in the past?

The old forms dictated that the challengers perform the ja'chuq. It's a long, involved ceremony where the challengers list the battles they've won, the prizes they've taken... the idea is to prove their worthiness to lead the Council.
Can the old form still be used?
It's up to you... you can use any form you want.
Captain... What do you know about Worf's discommendation?
My interest is... personal. I understand that you were there... you stood by him before the Council. I'd like to know what happened.
I'm sorry... but I cannot discuss it.
The Council must have a leader... now! Complete the rite so I can kill this ha'DIbah.
You will die slowly, Duras.
You've already proved you don't have the courage to face me... perhaps you should plant another bomb...
mev yap!
Sit down.
We will begin the ja'chuq.
What!
This woman is giving you bad advice, Picard. The ja'chuq is obsolete.
I choose to respect the ancient ritual. Each of you must prove your worthiness to lead the High Council.
That will take hours!
Or days... depending on your cooperation.
Kathless... the Unforgettable... he united the Homeworld in the year...
A tricorder... It is operated by activating the...
It is a bat'telh.
It belonged to my father... it has been in our family for ten generations.
Let me hold it.
No. Do not think of it as a weapon... make it part of your hand... your arm... make it part of you.
The next meeting is in three hours.
I would speak with you alone, Ambassador.
I'm honored.
Picard is prolonging the ja'chuq. Why?
He has sufficient reason to proceed carefully.
He relies on you for his knowledge of Klingon law...
Yes.
Then he values your advice. You could quicken the pace.
Possibly. Why should I?
Your position is... unique. Have you never wondered about serving the Klingon Empire?
I serve in my own way.
As a Federation Ambassador. A few rewards... but little glory.
What do you want?
What do you want? Command of a ship... a seat on the Council? There are many opportunities for you in the Empire.
Opportunities that will present themselves only if you come to power. You talk like a Ferengi.
K'mpec was also stubborn... he too refused to listen... now he's gone... you need not make the same mistake.
K'mpec was old and weak... I am not.
We've completed our analysis of the bomb debris.
The explosive was a triceron derivative.
The entire device couldn't have been more than three cubic millimeters in size...
Then it could have been hidden anywhere in the room.
There's one other thing, Commander... The bomb had a molecular-decay detonator.
Only one race uses that device, sir...
The Romulans.
How could Romulans have planted a bomb aboard a Klingon attack cruiser?
It would be impossible.
Not if the Romulans had help... from one of the Klingons.
Klingons and Romulans working together? They've been blood enemies for seventy-five years.
Perhaps Duras or Gowron wishes to improve that relationship.
A new Klingon alliance with the Romulans?
If true, it would represent a fundamental shift of power in the quadrant.
Indeed. It would put the Federation in a very uncomfortable position.
Gowron or Duras?
Gowron came to me alone... wanted me to speed up the ja'chuq... offered me a seat on the Council if I'd help him.
But does that suggest a Romulan connection?
He also implied that I would end up like K'mpec if I didn't cooperate.
Captain... I disagree. It must be Duras.
Why?
We have had prior dealings with Duras that showed him to be... untrustworthy.
Can you be more specific?
No.
Mister Worf, we now have a conspiracy on our hands that could be a direct threat to the security of the Federation.
Yes sir.
As Chief Security Officer, you will accompany me to the next transition proceeding.
Captain, they will be incensed. My presence will be... disruptive.
Yes. It will.
Deck Twenty-Three.
Halt.
You suspect Duras. Why?
I cannot---
Don't tell me that again! I'm trying to do my job while you withhold vital information...
I will not discuss this with you or anyone else.
Captain Picard seems well- informed. There's more at stake here than your personal honor.
I am aware of what is at stake here!
But you're still willing to hide the truth!
I am hiding nothing!
You're hiding everything, just like you always do... behind that precious Klingon honor. Why? Because you don't have the courage to face life without clinging to some archaic ritual?
Exit.
Computer, list stardates of the last Enterprise mission to the Klingon home planet.
Stardates 43685 through 43689.
How many ship's logs during that period?
Forty-three officer's logs. Ten personal logs.
Is there a personal log for Lieutenant Worf?
Affirmative. Access is restricted.
(a long beat, finally deciding) Eliminate all personal logs. List the other forty-three in chronological order... we'll take them one at a time...
jIH DoQ batlh! (I claim the honor!)
Both your claims have been properly made and recorded. We are ready for the final phase of the ja'chuq. There will be a recess while I review your petitions.
I know that you're as concerned as I am about the explosion aboard K'mpec's ship. I assume both of your investigations are continuing...
The investigations are complete. They revealed nothing of any importance.
That's very interesting... because our analysis turned up some startling results. Will you join us?
He has no place here, Picard!
I will not sit at the same table with that!
It is my prerogative to investigate anything relevant to the Rite of Succession. Lieutenant Worf is my chief of security. His presence is required.
We will not proceed...
I will determine how we proceed. If you wish to withdraw from the ja'chuq... that is your option.
What did your investigations reveal about the explosion?
It was a bomb.
Was your analysis just as... insightful?
It was a common explosive.
What type?
Triceron.
What about the detonator?
This is pointless! The findings were inconclusive.
Fortunately, our investigation was more... thorough.
The bomb used a molecular-decay detonator.
What!
A Romulan device.
I will return to my ship. I want to confirm these... conclusions myself.
As will I.
Lieutenant, please be sure to send a complete record of our findings to both vessels... and to the High Council. We are adjourned.
...Khitomer... Computer, why was the Enterprise crew studying the transmission logs from the Khitomer outpost?
Reference Chief Engineer's entry, stardate 43686.1. Certain transmission logs between the Khitomer outpost and the Romulan patrol ships were altered after the destruction of the colony.
Altered. By whom?
That information is not available.
Computer, interlock with the Klingon Imperial information net.
Interlock established.
Federation Ambassador K'Ehleyr requesting diplomatic access to High Council record. Security code pah doQ cha!
Proceed.
Computer, display summary of the most recent High Council inquiry regarding the Khitomer massacre.
Access denied. Restricted materials, du-ko-cha clearance only.
By whose order?
Council member Duras.
Access biographical files. Subject name: Councilor Duras.
Advise my counselors on the Vorn to convene... there is much to discuss... What is that...
Priority message to you from the home planet on a secure channel.
Excuse me, sir...
Sir, you cannot leave your quarters without an escort...
I am not helpless. I don't need a Starfleet escort.
I'm sorry, sir... Captain's orders. I'll be happy to call a security officer to accompany you...
It's an outrage. An insult. I will return to quarters.
Come.
I have been informed of your attempt to access restricted Council records.
I've been investigating what happened at Khitomer.
Not an easy task... considering that most of the records are sealed...
Worf's father was a traitor.
No, the evidence was altered to make it appear that way. I found it interesting to read that your father was also at Khitomer. And you are the one who sealed the records.
You would dare to insult my father's name?
Don't play the wounded Klingon for me, Duras... you don't do it very well. What happened in the council chambers... how did you get Worf to take the blame for you...
Do not pursue this matter further...
The son betrays his people to the Romulans just as his father did... Eh, Duras?
One of the Klingons who died in the explosion was with Duras... the other with Gowron. I've been examining the bodies... trying to get a clue to where the bomb was hidden.
There's always a pattern to the lacerations and tissue damage. It would normally give us a clear indication of direction, distance, force of impact...
'Normally'?
In this case, the pattern was virtually impossible to identify... I couldn't understand it until I checked the dynascans...
This wound is different from all the others... it was made from the inside out.
The bomb was implanted in one of their forearms.
It is considered an honorable way for a Klingon to die, Doctor... a suicide that also takes an enemy. Which one of them was it?
Duras' man.
When we have more time I will take you to the holodeck and demonstrate in more detail...
Medical Emergency, Deck Eight, Room one-four-two!
Gowron... ?
Duras?
Alexander...
You have never seen death?
Then look...
And always remember.
Stay with the doctor.
Worf, when did you... ?
Multiple stab wounds to the chest and abdomen... too much trauma to the internal organs. There wasn't enough time to get her into stasis.
Where's Worf?
I don't know... he left just after I got here.
Riker to Worf. Computer, locate Lieutenant Worf.
Lieutenant Worf is not aboard the Enterprise.
Where is he?
Lieutenant Worf transported to the Klingon ship Vorn at seventeen-thirty hours.
On my way.
How could you let him in here?
He has claimed the right of vengeance.
You have no rights here, traitor!
K'Ehleyr... was my mate.
And if Lieutenant Worf resists, sir?
He's coming back with us one way or another. Set phasers to maximum stun.
I'm the only one, Worf... the only one who can prove your innocence. Kill me... and you will always be known as a traitor.
Then that is how it shall be.
Worf!
Lieutenant, you are a fine officer... your service aboard this ship has been exemplary... Until now.
Sir, I acted within the boundaries of Klingon law and tradition.
The High Council seems to agree with you. They consider the matter to be closed. I do not.

The Enterprise crew currently includes representatives from thirteen planets, Mister Worf. They each have their individual beliefs and values and I respect them all. But every member of the crew has chosen to serve Starfleet. If anyone cannot perform his duties because of the demands of his society, he must resign.
Do you wish to resign, Lieutenant?
Captain...
I would hope you would not throw away a promising career.
No sir.
I understand your pain... we all felt very close to K'Ehleyr. A reprimand will be on your record. Dismissed.
Worf...

Isn't it time for the truth about your father's innocence to be told? After all, the reasons you accepted this dishonor were to protect the name of Duras, and hold the Empire together. Now that he's died in disgrace... where is the honor in further silence?

Each member of the Klingon high council shared in that lie. They will not be so willing to admit their own dishonor. But the day will come when my brother and I will... "convince" them to speak the truth.
My parents... my human parents will meet us at Starbase Seventy-Three. They will care for you.
Why can't I stay with you?
You deserve a home... a family. My parents can provide that... I cannot.
I miss her too.
Are you my father?
Yes... I am your father.
The truth is I'm a career man... you know, married to my job... Mitzi doesn't understand that... I like her a lot... but I just don't think I'm ready for two marriages if you know what I mean...
But at the same time, you know I wouldn't want to lose her...
Maybe you should come in with her and talk about it together.
Oh, I couldn't ask her to do that...
Sure you could. Why don't I make another appointment for you...
Counselor Troi... ?
Yes, Wesley...
Can I talk to you a minute... I have a real problem with my mother.
She's being completely unreasonable... see there's a party on Holodeck Four tonight... and all the other kids are staying overnight... well, most of them and...
Computer, dispatches...
A research inquiry from the Manitoba Journal of Interplanetary Psychology and three communiques from your mother...
Transfer my mother's letters to my viewer...
... and computer, I'd like a... a real chocolate sundae.
Define "real" in context, please.
Real... not one of your perfectly synthesized, ingeniously enhanced imitations... real chocolate ice cream, real whipped cream...
This unit is programmed to provide sources of nutritional value. Your request does not fall within current guidelines.
Listen, computer...
Do you wish to override program?
Picard to Counselor Troi.
Now what? Yes, Captain?
The pleasure of your company is requested, Counselor. We're having an impromptu reception for the arriving delegates.
Captain, I'm not dressed for a reception...
Oh, just throw on any old thing. We're about to get our first look at the wormhole.
Of course, Captain. I'm on my way. Troi out.
God forbid, I should miss the first look at the wormhole.
May I escort you in, Miss Troi...
Just tell me there's some chocolate here...
Ah, Counselor Troi... allow me to do the introductions... Premier Bhavani of the Barzan...
Your discovery has certainly produced a great deal of excitement, Premier.
Hopefully, it will also produce a new era of prosperity for my people.
We'll see to that...
You know Mister Mendoza, the Federation negotiator...
A pleasure to see you again, Counselor Troi.
One of the Federation's worthy competitors in the bidding, Leyor of the Caldonians.
Madame.
And I am Devinoni Ral.
Ship's Counselor Deanna Troi.
My traveling companion, Rojay.
My good friend, Ral, is the best hired gun in the business.
Hired gun?
My "good friend", Mendoza means that I am a negotiator who serves a variety of clients... on this occasion I represent the Chrysalians.
I believe it's almost time, isn't it Captain?
Indeed. It will be visible directly ahead...
Is it always on time, Bhavani?
Always. We see it every two hundred and thirty-three minutes... our scientists say it's due to radiation buildup in the acretion disk. The visible burst is very brief..
There it is, ladies and gentlemen. The Barzan Wormhole. The first and only stable wormhole known to exist. It's yours... for the right price.

Captain's log, Stardate 43385.7. We are in orbit around Barzan, a planet which is entertaining bids for control of what appears to be a most unique, stable wormhole. It could conceivably provide a permanent shortcut within our galaxy.

And as you all know, the environment on my planet is completely inhospitable to most other life forms. So I'd like to express my appreciation to you, Captain Picard, and your fine crew for hosting these negotiations aboard the Enterprise. Remember, Mister Mendoza, it doesn't give the Federation an advantage.

The Barzan has been a society dependent on others for generations. We want that to end. The appearance of this stable wormhole in our space provides us with our first true natural resource. We have neither the experience nor technology to exploit it. You do.
Excuse me, a delegation of... Ferengi... wishes to be beamed aboard...
You were not expecting the Ferengi, Premier... ?
No, but I do not wish to create ill will, Captain. If they are interested in bidding, I have no objection.
Chief O'Brien, this is Picard. Beam the Ferengi directly to the observation lounge.
Aye, Captain...
On behalf of all Ferengi, I protest... why were we not invited to these negotiations...
My apologies. We did not anticipate your interest. You are welcome to join us.
I am DaiMon Goss. These are my consuls... Kol and Doctor Arridor. We'll need chairs...
DaiMon, I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise... I'm serving as host for these proceedings...
Good, then see to it that we get chairs at once.
Perhaps you misunderstood...
Fine, fine, just have your Klingon servant...
I am in charge of security.
Then who gets the chairs?

DaiMon, due to the intimate nature of these negotiations, all parties agreed that one representative would suffice. I will be happy to provide your consuls with accommodations... and you may have my chair...
Very well. Kol, the bag...
We can handle all the pleasantries later. I'm sure I'll never remember your names anyway, eh? Enough of this foolishness. Let's get down to business.
I'll match anyone's best offer... and add the gold on top of it.
Computer... show me the file on delegate Devinoni Ral...
Devinoni Ral, human, age forty-one, born Brussels, European Alliance, relocated at age nineteen to Hurkos Three, a non-aligned planet...
Come in.
Should I call for an appointment... ?
No... I... was just looking over some personnel files...
Too bad. I had hoped you might be thinking about... me.
I thought you'd be deep into negotiations by now...
In recess. I never play the opening rounds, anyway. Inconsequential.
Besides there are more interesting things to negotiate on this ship. Like dinner tonight?
What about your... traveling companion?
My traveling companion... is traveling. I sent her home.
Why?
You know why.
Weren't you getting along?
Don't do that.
What?
Don't do "Counselor" Troi.
Was I?
When you leave this office, who are you?
Oh. So that's how it is.
You never do. You never leave the office.
What are you...
Ssshh...
Dinner at eight?
The data from the Barzan's probe into the wormhole is impressive, Captain. The wormhole delivered the probe beyond the Denkiri Arm, in the Gamma Quadrant.
It would take us nearly a century at warp nine to cross that distance...
The same distance could be achieved in a matter of seconds through the wormhole.
I was just imagining the Ferengi collecting tolls in front if we lose to them...
I don't think the Ferengi are the greatest threat at the table... with all of DaiMon Goss' bluster, they don't have the resources the Barzans need.
I'd say that fellow Devinoni's the one to watch out for...
An accurate observation... what made you recognize that?
He's the most comfortable man in the group...
You must play poker, Commander...
Poker, isn't that a game of some sort?
Commander Riker teaches poker.
Our skills are not dissimilar, Commander.
Mister Mendoza, if this lives up to its billing... it is a discovery of extraordinary value... but it is a big "if"...
Wormholes are here one moment, gone the next... a stable wormhole is unheard of.
Are you saying this may not be what it seems?

The Barzans do not have manned space travel, so they had to resort to an automated probe. Its findings are limited. It cannot be determined from these charts how stable the wormhole really is or how long it will remain intact.
The Federation could wind up "buying" itself the proverbial lemon, Mister Mendoza.
And once the contract is negotiated and closed, we would be obliged to fulfill the terms.
We really ought to see for ourselves.
I don't think Bhavani could object to that...
Geordi has continuous visual contact with the wormhole, Captain. He's the logical choice...
I would also like to volunteer, Captain...

Before anyone goes in there, we're going to conduct a full sensor analysis. I want to do everything possible to determine that it's safe. If we're satisfied, Data, you and Commander La Forge will enter the wormhole tommorrow.
Just a moment of discomfort for a good cause, DaiMon.
You understand this will not be lethal.
Doctor, you surprise me. I have no wish to kill anyone. A short term crippling will suffice.
Then, this will be just fine.
A distillation of your own blood pyrocytes... harmless to you...
undetectable by the ship's bio-filters... but when absorbed through your victim's skin, it will provoke an extreme allergic reaction.
I'd say it is time to extend the hand of the Ferengi to the representative of the Federation.
Much... better.
Thank you. Come in for a drink?
Ah, Federation decor...
Not your style?
Conformity is not my style.
What would you like?
I'd even like another.
There she is again... Counselor Troi...
I am not... computer, champagne...
... for two...
Am I moving too fast for you?
No, I'm moving too fast for me.
Mmm, I like that better...
(and now she looks at him) I haven't been able to stop thinking about you all day...
You must've had a nice day.
Anticipation is fun.
We'll be late for dinner.
Very late.
Mister Mendoza?
I seem to be a bit warm...
I need some help here...
You attempt to gain every unfair advantage, Picard...
Premier Bhavani has no objection...

Well, I most certainly do... First, you conveniently arrange to play host... now you plan to send your own manned probe into the wormhole... the Federation thinks it can do anything it wants to. And I will not tolerate it any longer...
We will gladly share the results of our exploration with all the delegates...
And you expect us to believe what you report?
Then send in your own probe, Goss.
That's exactly what I intend to do. And I strongly suggest you stay out of our way.
Tell Data and La Forge to do themselves a favor and stay out of their way.
Captain Picard, please come to Sickbay...
Acknowledged, Doctor.
Whatever he's got is obviously not life threatening -- it's some kind of system-wide histaminic reaction. He certainly can't go back to the negotiations for several days.
Keep us advised.
The Federation's top negotiator taken out by a mysterious ailment. Suspicions?
With the Ferengi around, always.
Well, I guess you'll have to fill in for him, Number One.
Me?
I am the designated host. It would be a most awkward transition. The next likely choice is you. Mister Mendoza would agree. He was quite impressed with your natural instincts.
Excuse me, sir, but those weren't natural instincts... they're poker instincts... A parlor game doesn't exactly prepare me for this...
Yes, the stakes are higher. But then... that's when the game gets interesting, doesn't it, Commander.
The wormhole will reappear in thirty seconds.
Shuttle nine, stand by...
Ferengi pod is moving into position, Captain...
Ferengi pod, this is Lieutenant Commander La Forge in the Enterprise shuttle.
This is Doctor Arridor, go ahead.
Would you care to take the point, Doctor?
We will gladly yield that honor to you, Lieutenant Commander.
Proceed when ready.
Contact with the shuttle, sir.
Pipe it in, Lieutenant.
Captain, we have penetrated the outer event horizon of the wormhole. Sensors read severe doppler shifts...
It's the relativistic time dilation, sir. Time is moving more slowly inside their part of the wormhole. I can process the audio to compensate...
Make it so.
... and intense energy fields which appear to be stabilizing the wormhole. It is not clear why... Now approaching the singularity...
They've passed beyond our communication capabilities, sir...
Commander, I appreciate what a difficult position this is for you. If you don't understand something, I hope you won't be embarrassed to ask me...
I think I have an idea what the rules are.
That's what makes it so interesting... the rules of the game change to fit the moment.
In that regard, it's not unlike commanding a starship, Mister Ral.
Commander, Mister Mendoza has already presented many of the details of the Federation proposal. Is there anything you would like to add?
A complete analysis of our bid is available on the ship's computer for your consideration, Premier... If I may summarize...
Our proposal includes technology that will enhance your food production, your mining capabilities, and space travel.

We offer scholars and scientists to investigate the wormhole's potential. And perhaps most critical of all, we offer Starfleet. The security of this passage must never be compromised. We offer protection of the wormhole in perpetuity.
Mister Ral... ?
(a beat, as though reluctant) Mister Riker's placed a great deal of emphasis on defense... a subject he obviously knows well, having served Starfleet in many a conflict.
The Chrysalians are enemies of no one... and choose to remain that way. Neutral.
Neutral. And uninvolved, sir, in virtually all interstellar matters of consequence.
No one would claim that the Chrysalians are as powerful as the mighty Federation, but we have resources and technology and scientists too. We have also had peace for ten generations.
This is a fine proposal, Commander.
I was just thinking...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Mmmm?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Maybe I could stretch out these negotiations a few extra days.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Mmmm.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Would you like that?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Mmm-hmmm.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Devinoni Ral, who are you?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: What do your Betazoid senses tell you about me?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Not very much... My human physical response must be blocking them out.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Good.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: It's never happened before.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I rather like it that I'm more difficult to read than your other men...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I don't have any others... currently.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: How about Commander Riker?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Who have you been talking to... ?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: No one. I just sensed something when I saw the two of you together.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Will Riker and I are good friends.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Uh huh...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: It was once a little more than that.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Mmmm-hmm...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: And how come we're talking about me and not you?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Don't you have enough people telling you about their lives? Who counsels the counselor?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Uh uh, I want to know about you now...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I am a man of commerce. And I'm what you see right now. No games, no strategies. Just me, wanting to run away with you. And knowing that if I asked you, you'd never leave this damned ship.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: When I first saw you, I felt as if I'd been waiting for you. I've been trying to understand why or how that's possible.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: Does it matter?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: It will... when I tell you. But you must promise never to tell anyone else.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: What?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I am partly Betazoid too. My mother was half... I am one quarter.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: You're empathic?
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: The only one of five children. I must admit I was never as comfortable sensing emotions as you seem to be...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: That's why you left Earth...
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I've learned to live with it, use it... as you have... but still, it isolates us, doesn't it... ? I thought it would always be that way for me. Now, all of a sudden the rules I live by don't mean anything any more. I had tucked my heart away... didn't need it, didn't want it. At the negotiating table it can be fatal to have a heart... but I never realized how much I missed it until I looked at you.
scene: 47   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON HER FOOT

quote: I'm picking up an increase in accretion matter filtering in from the terminus.
We made it...
Monitors are functioning normally again.
Ferengi pod, everybody in one piece over there?
Our condition is no concern of yours, Enterprise shuttle. We are competitors in this venture, not partners. Ferengi pod, out.
Happy landings to you too.
Curious.
Huh?
We are not where we are supposed to be.
What do you mean... we're on the other side of the wormhole, aren't we... ?
According to the Barzan probe, we should be in the Gamma Quadrant... but the readings clearly indicate we are nearly two hundred light years away. In sector three-five-five-six of the Delta Quadrant.
Maybe the Barzan's readings were wrong...
Maybe their readings were correct. Their probe could have exited the wormhole at a different location.
Data, I'm picking up a subatomic fluctuation... meson and lepton activity is increasing...
Gravitational acceleration is also increasing...
Something very strange is happening to this wormhole.
Sorry.
You're unusually "limber" this morning.
I'll say.
Uh huh... ?
Devinoni Ral.
It's ridiculous. And wonderful. I feel... completely out of control. Happy. Terrified. There's nothing rational about this.
Who needs rational when your toes curl up... ?
I'm afraid I'm going to lose myself... I can't get enough of him. Is it possible to fall in love in one day?
I did.
It was like this for you and Jack?
No, it was another fellow. Fell in love in a day. It lasted a week. But what a week. Then I met Jack... took months to figure it out with Jack.
Maybe I should slow down... catch my breath, not let this get out of control...
Nah.
To be honest, I was surprised to see the Caldonians here at all, Leyor...
You must think Caldonia very insular, Mister Ral.
Not at all... on the contrary, I've respected your world's commitment to pure research. It's just that, well...
Go ahead, please...
Well, scholars don't always enjoy administrative demands...
And certainly we've seen here that the administration of the wormhole...
Yes... I must admit I have begun to feel some trepidation about that...
I'm sure you have. I'm sure we all have, Leyor... Do you realize that during the next century, the number of ships...
Gentlemen, this open session is called by request of the Caldonian delegation.
Madame Bhavani, Caldonia withdraws from these proceedings.
For what reasons, Leyor?
It has been made very clear that the maintenance and administrative requirements are beyond our ability...
Leyor, the Federation would like to negotiate a trade agreement to acquire your planet's rich deposits of Trillium 323 which we will add to our bid, Premier Bhavani...
My apologies. We have already reached an agreement with the Chrysalians...
Mister Ral, you either had very good instincts -- or foreknowledge of the Caldonian withdrawal.
Some people just don't wish to transact business with the Federation, Commander. The Chrysalians hereby add the Caldonian Trillium 323 to its bid, Premier...
I have no intention of leaving yet. We are not finished taking our readings...
I'm telling you, it's changing... Look, your readings must be showing you the same things we're getting... this is not the Gamma Quadrant.
I will not confirm your speculations...
It is not a speculation, Doctor. We are not where the Barzans said we should be... which would indicate that this side of the wormhole is not stable.
There are meson and lepton fluctuations... local gravitational fields are increasing exponentially... everything says we better get the hell out of here...
It will be visible again in forty seconds... we will make our own judgments then...
I can see it now... and I'm telling you that you don't have time to wait... not even forty seconds...
Ferengi pod, out.
Dammit, Arridor, we're seventy thousand light years away from our ships... follow us... we'll lead you in...
Idiots.
It's getting worse. I'm taking us in, Data... with or without them...
Thrusters at half power... three-quarters...
Entering outer event horizon...
They panic quickly under pressure.
There, precisely as scheduled, right where I expected it to be.
Everyone's talking about the way you absorbed the Caldonian bid today...
It was there for the taking... So I took it...
Commander Riker didn't know how you managed it...
Let me tell you something, Will Riker's good... the most dangerous man in the room to me... he has every instinct of a fine negotiator...
... he just doesn't have an edge. Your edge.
Our edge... and you make it sound unethical.
Isn't it?
Deanna, it's just business...
Why haven't you told anyone that you're an empath?
I find it makes people uncomfortable.
I think you don't tell them... so you can gain an advantage.
I used it to gain an advantage with you... and you didn't mind...

The point of negotiating is to take advantage, Deanna. I don't know what the other side is offering, they don't know what I'm offering. We dance around each other until someone wins. I never cry foul when I lose.
But you're reading their emotional states, their inner selves, then using that to manipulate them.
Deanna, people have been doing that for thousands of years, by listening carefully, by watching body language. I just happen to be better at it. You do it.
I do it to help my crew, not outmanueuver them. And I don't hide that I'm an empath.

You announce it to every alien culture you encounter? Or do you use it to give your side an advantage. Do you tell the Romulan in the ship about to attack that you can feel that he's bluffing or do you just tell it to your captain?
That's different. It's a matter of protection...

Your protection... your captain, your crew... your edge. Yes. It's a matter of life and death when you take the advantage. Me, I deal in property, in exchange... no one gets hurt. Which of us would you say has the greater problem of ethics?
May I join you, Commander?
Bought out the Ferengi yet, Ral?
Think I should try?
No. But I think you will. One way or another, it'll come down to you and me.
You know, you're very good at this... better than you realize.
I hope I'm better than you realize, Ral.
The last mile of the marathon is always the toughest. That's when the winners are willing to take the big risks... are you ready to do that?
We'll see, won't we...
Well, let's see right now... I'm prepared to reach a firm agreement with Bhavani before we learn the results of your probe's expedition. Are you?
Mmmm, that would not be looked upon favorably by the Federation, I'd imagine.
See, you have to be willing to take that last step alone... or it isn't worth playing.
Your point of view, not mine.
Oh, I see that, Commander... otherwise you wouldn't be second in command of this ship.
You know, I feel responsible for you in a way... related. Deanna. We both love Deanna... in different ways, of course.
I'll remove the burden of that responsibility right now. My relationship with Deanna stands on its own. Without help from you.
Of course it does. She's an extraordinary woman. Lovely, brilliant --- very passionate.
She could have been yours, Will. But you didn't do enough to keep her, and now, I'm here and I'm going to take her too.
You know, I think this is the first bad play I've seen you make...

If you bring happiness into Deanna's life, nothing would please me more. You're not really a bad sort, Ral, you just don't have any values... beyond the value of today's bid, that is. She's just the one to give some meaning to your sorry existence... if you're smart enough to take it. I doubt that you are.
To the last mile.
Federation women have a game they call "playing hard to get".
Yes, I do not at all find it amusing.
On Chrysalia, the women outnumber the men four to one. They virtually throw themselves at your feet...
Sir, the Ferengi vessel is moving out of orbit, impulse power... They are approaching the entry to the wormhole, sir.
Computer, is the Ferengi Goss still aboard the Enterprise?
DaiMon Goss departed the Enterprise at fourteen hundred hours.
Ferengi are powering forward missile launchers...
Yellow Alert. Hail the Ferengi.
DaiMon Goss responding.
On screen.
Request an explanation for your actions, DaiMon Goss.
I have learned from informed sources that the Federation has manipulated these negotiations from the very beginning... and has already signed a secret agreement with the Barzans.
That is not true...
The Ferengi offer was never seriously considered.
Premier Bhavani welcomed you to these proceedings, Goss... despite my better judgment...
We will be ignored no longer.
They've fired a missile directly at the opening, sir!
Destroy it.
Firing phasers.
Your offers both have merit, gentlemen... if I could find a deciding factor...
Riker to Picard. What's happening, Captain?
Goss has fired a missile at the wormhole... I need you on the bridge, Number One...
Excuse me.

Excuse me for saying so under the circumstances, Premier... But this fight is really between the Federation and the Ferengi... it is unconscionable that your wormhole is being used as a pawn in their power struggle.
You must know we will not allow you to do this, Goss.
If the Ferengi cannot have the wormhole, no one will...
Can he possibly believe that a missile will have any destructive effect on a wormhole?
One of those missiles would have a destructive effect if it exploded near our shuttle...
Goss... don't you realize we both have shuttlecraft in there?
Casualties of war, Commander. My men are prepared to die. Are yours?
Captain...
Viewscreen off.
He's lying. I'm almost sure of it. He does not mean what he says.
Why... what is he doing it for then?
Permission to enter the bridge, Captain...
Premier, with all due respect...
Captain, I believe I am in a better position to settle this with DaiMon Goss than you are... May I address him?
DaiMon Goss, this is Devinoni Ral...
I have nothing to say to you, Ral.

Then, just listen. The planet of Barzan has reached an agreement with the Chrysalians for long term control of the wormhole. On behalf of the Chrysalians, I am prepared to offer the Ferengi free access to the wormhole in perpetuity...
I have your word on this?
My word, sir. In return for some Ferengi convoy privileges to be negotiated in good faith.
This is an acceptable offer.
Ferengi vessel has shut down forward missile launchers.
Stand down, Red Alert.

Commander Riker, I'm sorry you had to learn about my decision this way. You represented the Federation well. But I have come to believe that the Chrysalians' neutrality and tradition of peace is more desirable to my planet.
Excuse me, Premier. There is something you should know...
I'm sorry, was there something you wanted to say, Mister Ral?
No... not at all...
I sense you are uncomfortable suddenly...
Well, after all, this was a tense situation...
But that's what is so odd about it... it was not tense at all... I sensed no tension from DaiMon Goss... or you...
I was tense... I was ready to blow it up... I strongly protest...
Off screen.
It was almost as though... you both were performing a scene for all of us...
Excuse me, Captain, I think there's a slight conflict of interest here...
I agree. Entirely. Devinoni asked me not to tell anyone about his empathic powers... which he uses to manipulate competitors in a negotiation.

Certainly, that put me in a conflict of interest which I hope I have now resolved. Premier, I believe Ral has used your fear of continuing aggression between the Federation and its enemies to undermine our position. I also believe this incident was staged by Ral and Goss to provide you with a reason to decide in favor of the Chrysalians.
Captain...
(knows by the sound in his voice) On speaker.
Shuttle nine to Enterprise... Shuttle nine to Enterprise...
Shuttle, this is Picard... do you read... On screen...
This is Shuttle nine... reporting back... barely.
The Ferengi pod?
They're trapped on the other side, sir. In the Delta Quadrant. We tried to warn them. They wouldn't follow us.
Elaborate.

Captain, this end of the wormhole is currently stable but the other end apparently shifts position periodically. The Barzan probe had no way to recognize this. Eventually, both sides will be unstable.
It's a dry well, Captain. Worthless.
Acknowledged, Shuttle nine. Main Shuttlebay, prepare for final approach.
Captain, DaiMon Goss is demanding to know where his men are.
Advise him to set his coordinates for the Delta Quadrant, Lieutenant... He might run into them in eighty years or so.
Mister Ral, I congratulate you on winning the rights to the Barzan wormhole...
I take the risks. I stand by my agreements.
Come in...
When do you leave?
Soon. I've... been recalled by the Chrysalians... explanations demanded and so forth.
I'm sorry.
I've done all right for them over the years... they know the stakes. It'll be fine.
I had to do it, Troi...
Bhavani was ready to go with the the Federation. I sensed it. And I'd used up every card in the deck... I had to change the rules.
You must have known that I couldn't allow you to do that...
My human physical response must have blocked out my Betazoid senses.
In a way, I'm glad you did it. It's made me take a hard look at who I am. I don't like what I see.
Deanna... I once asked you to run away with me. I'm asking you again. I need you. You could help me change. You could be my conscience.
I already have a job as a counselor.
Hot chocolate, please.
We don't ordinarily say "please" to food dispensers.

Since it's listed as "intelligent Circuitry", why not? After all, working as much with artificial intelligence as we do, can be dehumanizing -- right? So, maybe we can combat that tendency with a little simple courtesy.
Thank you.
For someone who has just arrived, you certainly aren't shy with your opinions.
Ooops -- have I been talking too much?
No.

(the words come out in a rush) I do tend to be a motor mouth, especially when I get excited... and you don't know how exciting it is to get this assignment. Everyone in class -- and I mean everyone -- wants the Enterprise. I mean, it would have been all right to spend some time on Ranuos Six to do phase work with anti-matter... that's my speciality.
I know -- that's why you got this assignment.
Did it again. It's just that...
I know, you're excited. Sonya.
Yes.
I don't think you want to bring that hot chocolate around these control stations.
Sorry. I shouldn't even have this in engineering. We were talking and I just forgot I had it in my hand...
I'll finish it over here. (looks back, and seriously) Lieutenant La Forge, it won't happen again.
Actually it's my fault, sir...
Yes, I'm aware of how often you order picnics to be held in here.
Oh no. Oh, Captain... I'm sorry... oh.. (she tries to brush it off) ... I wasn't looking and... (she pulls her hand away) Oh.. It's all over you.
Yes, Ensign. It's all over me.
At least let me...
Ensign... ah...
(she straightens up to her best military posture) Ensign Sonya Gomez.
Ensign Gomez is a recent Academy graduate. She transferred on at Starbase one seventy three.
Ensign... I think it would be simpler if you let me change my uniform?
Captain, I really have to accept responsibility for this.
Yes, Chief Engineer. I believe I do understand now.
I'm very excited about this assignment Captain, and I promise I'll... (she looks at the chocolate stain on Picard's uniform) ... try very hard to serve you and this ship to the best of my ability.
I'm sure you will. Carry on.
First impressions right. Isn't that what they say -- first impressions are the most important.
I'll give you this... it's a meeting the captain won't soon forget.
What a way to start my first assignment.
Deck nine. Officers' quarters.
Crewman? What's going on?
There, there, my dear captain.
Q.
My, my -- haven't we been careless.
There -- a little cleaning service. I am more than happy to provide.
We agreed you would never trouble my ship again!
I always keep my arrangements, sir. We are nowhere near your vessel.
I read your graduating thesis. I wouldn't have requested you if you weren't the best.
Where are we going?
To Ten-Forward. We're going to forget about work. We are going to sit, talk, relax, look at the stars. You're going to learn to slow down.
No, that's the one thing I can't do.
You're awfully young to be so driven.

Yes, I am. I had to be. I had to be the best because only the best get to be here. Out here on the edge. (gripping his arm and giving it a shake) Geordi, Geordi . . .uh . . (dropping the arm abruptly) Lieutenant --
Geordi
Geordi. Whatever is out here we're going to be the first humans ever to see it. And is it here because we believe in it and have therefore created it, or has it created us?
The Grand Unified Theory and Supersymmetry hasn't been seriously discussed for years.
They also haven't been disproved. I don't know if it's true or not, but I've got to try and find out.
You're more than a scientist you're a philospher.
No, no, I'm not. Oh, God, don't make me sound profound. There's just so much out there ... here.
I have to see it all. To understand it all, and we haven't got much time.
Sonya, it's going to be there for you. Believe me. I promise, I won't let anything exciting slip past without letting you know.
I understand that you're excited -- so was I. This is your first assignment, everything is new, you are eager and that's great, but...
I've always been an enthusiastic person, but...
Do me a favor... for a minute, just listen.
I always do that. Someone nice -- and you are nice I can tell, goes out of their way to give me some helpful advice... and I'm so busy talking...
Not another word. Go ahead... talk.
Bridge, this is Ten-Forward.
Guinan?! I don't believe you've ever called the bridge before.
I've never felt the need. Is everything alright?
How do you mean?
Is there... anything... unusual happening?
Anyone notice anything unusual? No Guinan, nothing out of the ordinary. Why do you ask?
I'm... I'm not certain. Just a feeling -- something that happened once before. Probably nothing. Please forget I called. Ten- Forward out.
The locator beacon won't help. They'll never look for you this far away.
Enterprise -- this is Picard.
Stop this foolishness, Q. Return me to the Enterprise.
I'd suggest you change your attitude. Petulance does not become you. We have business.
Keeping me a prisoner out here will not force me to discuss anything with you.
It will in time, my dear Captain.
I appreciate your advice, Lieutenant. And, I'll take it to heart.
Guinan?
Can I get you something?
No -- we're fine. Is everything all right?
I don't know.
I think I'll go check out Engineering.
I'll go with you.
Where's the captain?
In his Ready Room.
Captain -- this is Counselor Troi.
Computer -- locate Captain Picard.
The captain is not on the ship.
Commander, there is a shuttle missing from Shuttle Bay Two.
All stop.
Answering all stop.
I have hailed the shuttle on all frequencies -- no response.
Sensors indicate no shuttle or other ships in this sector.
We must assume the captain is onboard the shuttle.
But, how could he get to the shuttle bay, how could he leave the Enterprise without us knowing? It's not possible.

Take it easy, Wes. We'll find him. I want to begin a methodical search. Sensors on maximum scan We'll use our present location as the center. Data plot a search pattern from our present coordinates which will cover the most area in the shortest time.
The search pattern has been input.
Engage, Mister Crusher.

First officer's log. Stardate . We have not been able to determine why, or how, Captain Picard left the Enterprise. We can't even be certain he is in the missing shuttle, although that is the assumption on which we are proceeding. For the last six hours we have been searching without success.
We have covered the area in a spherical pattern which a vessel without warp drive could traverse in the time allotted.
Widen the area...
Do we stay out here years? Decades? Picard, I am ageless -- you are not.
Then the Enterprise will continue on with Riker as captain. Return me to my ship.
You are an impossibly stubborn human.
If I return you to your ship, you will agree to give my request a full hearing?
You're right Picard. This is the proper venue for our discussion.
Commander. My status board indicates that the shuttle is back in Shuttle Bay Two.
Computer -- locate Captain Picard.
Captain Picard is in Ten-Forward.
You!
None other.
Picard, if you had half the sense you pretend to have, you would get her off your ship immediately -- and if you like I will be more than pleased to expedite her departure.
You know him.
We had some dealings.
Those dealings were two centuries ago. This creature is not what she appears to be. She's an imp -- where she goes trouble always follows.
You're speaking of yourself, Q -- not Guinan.
Guinan? Is that your name now?
Guinan's not the issue here -- you are... We had an agreement that you would stop meddling with us.
And so I have.
What do you want, Q? State your business and let's get on with it.
I agree Captain, enough about this creature -- she's diverting us from the purpose of my being here.
Which is?
Ahh, the redoubtable Commander Riker. And micro-brain. Growl for me -- let me know you still care.
My purpose? Why to join you.
To join us as what?
A member of the crew. Willing and able -- ready to serve.
This ship is already home for the indigent, the unwanted and the unworthy -- so why not a homeless entity.
Homeless?
Yes.
So, the other members of the Q continuum kicked you out.
Not all of the Q are like this one. Some are almost respectable.
Join us as what? To do what? Would you start as an ordinary crewman -- what task is too menial for an entity?
Do you mock me?

Not at all. That is the last thing I would do. You, by definition are part of our charter. Our mission is to go forth -- to seek out new and different life forms, and you certainly qualify as one of the most unique life forms I have ever encountered. To learn more about you is frankly quite provocative, but you are next of kin to chaos.
Captain, at least allow me to present my argument.

After our last encounter, I was asked to leave the Q continuum. Since then, I have been wandering vaguely -- bored really -- my existence without purpose. Then, I remembered the good times I had with you...
The good times!? The first time we met you put us on trial for the "crimes of humanity"...
Of which you were exonerated.
The next time we saw you, you asked me to join the Q continuum.
You made a large mistake in not accepting my offer.
... and now you say you want to join us.

Yes, more and more I realize that here -- here is where I want to be. Think of the advantages. Now, I neither expect nor require any special treatment. If necessary, although I can't imagine why, I will renounce my powers and become as weak and incompetent as all of you.
No.
Oh, come on, Captain, in fairness... let me try, I deserve at least that much.
Fairness?! You disrupt this ship -- kidnap the captain!
I add a little excitement, a little spice to your lives and all you do is complain. Where's your adventurous spirit -- your imagination. Think, Picard, of the possibilities.
Simply stated -- we don't trust you.
Oh, you may not trust me, but you do need me. You're not prepared for what awaits you.
I don't know that we are prepared, but I do know that we are ready to confront it.
Really?
Absolutely. That's why we are out here.
Oh, the arrogance. They don't have a clue about what's "out here".
They will learn -- adapt. That's their great advantage.
They are moving faster than expected -- farther than they should.
By whose calculation?
You judge yourselves against the pitiful adversaries you have so far encountered -- the Klingons, the Romulans, are nothing compared to what's waiting.

Picard, you are about to move into areas of the galaxy containing wonders more incredible than you can possibly imagine... and terrors to freeze your soul. I offer myself as guide -- only to be rejected out-of-hand.
I guess we'll just have to get along the best we can without you.
What justifies this smugness?
We're not smug -- nor arrogant. We are resolute and we are willing. But more than that we are determined. Your help is not required.
Well, let's just see how ready you are.
Q -- don't do this!
Bridge this is the captain -- all stop.
Answering all stop.
Status.
According to these coordinates we have traveled seven thousand light years, and are located near system J-two-five.
Estimate travel time to the closest starbase.
At maximum warp, in two years, seven months, three days, eighteen hours we would reach Starbase one eight five.
Why?

Why? Why, to give you a taste of your future. This is a preview of things to come, because if you continue at your present rate of exploration -- very soon you will reach this part of the galaxy. Con permiso, Capitan. The hall has been rented -- the orchestra engaged -- it's time to see if you can dance.
Guinan, have your people been in this part of the galaxy?
Yes.
What can you tell us?
Only that if I were you, I'd start back right now.
Captain's log, supplemental. The entity Q has flung the Enterprise to a distant part of the galaxy, which we are going to take the opportunity to explore.
Captain, the sixth planet in the system is Class M.
There is a system of roads on the planet which indicate a highly industrialized civilization. But where there should be cities there are only great rips in the surface.
It is as though some great force just scooped all machine elements off the face of the planet.
It is identical to what happened to the outposts along the Neutral Zone.
We are being probed.
What's the source of the probe?
A ship. It is on an intercept course.
On screen.
Magnify.
Full scan. Go to Yellow Alert.
Going to Yellow Alert.
Keep the shields down -- we don't want to appear provocative.
Data, what can you tell us?
The ship is strangely generalized in design. There is no specific bridge or central control area, no specific engineering section -- I can identify no living quarters.
Life signs?
There is no indication of specific life.
Lieutenant Worf, what is its alert status?
I detect no shields, no weapons of any known design.
Hailing frequencies.
Open.
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise.
No response.
Guinan.
Activate your viewscreen -- I want you to monitor what's going on up here. I may need your input.
I'm here. I can see the other ship.
You are acquainted with this life form?
Yes. My people encountered them a century ago. Our cities were destroyed -- our people scattered across the galaxy. They are called the Borg -- protect yourself or they will destroy you.
Shields up.
Yes, sir.
Security to Main Engineering -- we have an intruder.
He came right through the shields!
Interesting isn't it? Not a he -- not a she. Not like anything you've ever seen. An enhanced humanoid.
What do you want?
We mean you no harm. Do you understand me?
Understand you? You are nothing to him. He has no interest in your life form. He's just a scout -- the first of many. He's here to analyze as much about you as he can -- that's how they always start.
He may attempt to gain control of the ship. I wouldn't let him.
Stop -- we cannot allow you to interfere with the operation of this ship.
Lieutenant Worf.
Worf -- use whatever means to neutralize the intruder.
Because her people had contact with the Borg, I have requested that Guinan participate in this conference. You are aware of what just occurred in Main Engineering.
Tell, us exactly what happened between your people and the Borg.
I was not personally invloved, but -- from what I have been told they came through our system like a storm of Jaradan Aser beatles -- and by the time they left, there wasn't much left of our society.
Guinan, if they are that aggressive, then I wonder why neither Borg attacked? They could have -- but they didn't.
They never do that as individuals. It's just not their way. When they decide to come, they will come in force. They do nothing piecemeal.
Then the initial encounter was solely for the purpose of gathering information.
Yes.
How do we reason with them? Let them know that we are not a threat?
You don't, at least to my knowledge nobody has so far.
Captain, we are being hailed.
On screen.
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the...
We have analyzed your defensive capabilities as being unable to withstand us. If you defend yourselves, you will be punished.
Counselor.
You are not dealing with an individual mind. They do not have a single leader. It is the collective minds of all of them.
That would have some definite advantages.
Yes. A single leader can make errors. It is less likely for the combined whole.
Picard.
Are you certain you still don't want me as a member of your crew? This would be the time to ask, before everything goes too far beyond your control.
Captain -- they have locked onto us with some form of tractor beam.
We're on our way.
Whatever this beam is, Captain, it is draining our shields.
If they pull down our shields we're helpless.
On any heading -- warp eight engage.
It's holding us here!
Increase power!
The shields are weakening.
In eighteen seconds the shields will be down.
Locate the exact source of the tractor beam -- lock on phasers.
Phasers locked on target.
Fire.
They still have us.
Shields are down.
A type of laser beam is slicing into the Saucer Section.
They are carving us up like a roast.
With whatever force you need terminate that beam.
Fire!
The tractor beam has released.
Damage report.
Sections twenty-seven, twenty-eight and twenty- nine on Decks four, five and six destroyed.
Casualties?
Eighteen were in those sections and are missing.
They couldn't have survived it.
A force field is maintaining hull integrity.
What is the condition of their ship?
They have sustained damage to twenty percent of their vessel. Life support minimal.
Why?!
Conference.
Worf -- you had better remain at your station.
I am so sorry, Captain.
Guinan -- what else can you tell us about these creatures?
I only know bits and pieces.
Anything would be helpful.
They are a mixture of organic and artificial life that has been developed over a thousand centuries.
I can't get the shields up.
Divert power from wherever you need it. Anywhere except life support.
It wouldn't help. The circuits which control the shields have been fused.
If you can't reprogram them... reroute.
Eighteen people. Dead -- just like that.
Push it out of your head.
I can't. I keep seeing them.
Stop it. We'll grieve later. Right now... let's get those shields operative.

The Borg is the ultimate user, with the result that they are unlike any threat your Federation has ever faced. They have no interest in political conquest -- or wealth or power as you know it. They simply want your ship -- its technology. They have identified it as something they can consume and use.
And you brought us here, exposed us to it, cost us the lives of shipmates...
Stop -- or you will surely die.
Number One.
Eighteen of our people have died. Please tell us that this is one of your illusions.
Oh, no. This is as real as your "so called" life gets.
This is Lieutenant La Forge, Captain. We have been able to restore power to the shields.
Very good.
Captain, I have the casuality list coming on screen.
Cancel -- time for that later.
If there's a chance we are going to have further dealings with the Borg -- now or in the future -- we had better find out as much about them as we can.
Visit their ship?
In my opinion, we have no choice, sir.
Agreed. Assemble a minimal away team and take a look at what's over there.
What?
Mister Worf. Report to Transporter Room 3. Data.
It's not my business but I wouldn't go over there if I were you.
Oh, I don't know, Guinan. They visited us... seems only fair that we return the courtesy.

Captain's log, supplemental. We have been attacked without provocation by an alien race which Guinan calls the Borg. Hopefully, we have neutralized their vessel. Commander Riker is leading an away team in an attempt to learn more about them.
There are no life sign readings.
I have laid in coordinates which should set you down in the least damaged section of the Borg ship.
Set phasers on stun, but let's be ready to increase the power if we need it.
Energize.
I wonder why they don't react to us, and why the Enterprise did not read any life signs, especially when there are this many.
Perhaps because this ship was scanned for individual life signs. Apparently when they are in these slots, they become part of the whole and no longer read as separate life forms.
(touches his communicator) Captain.
Go ahead, Number One.
Our readings were incorrect... the Borg crew survived, but they are in a kind of stasis.
Explain.
There are slots along the wall, kind of like compartments. There are two Borg in each.
Captain, I would theorize that the Borg are somehow interconnected through these slots and are working collectively.
We are going to look for some way to access their main computer.
Each slot is designed for a specific Borg. Here is where the connection is made. (he indicates a type of arm rest)
Like a juggernaut which could start moving at any moment.
The technology required to achieve this biological and artificial interface is far beyond our capabilities. There are many advantages.
Speed being the obvious one. This ship literally thinks what it wants to do and it happens.
Fascinating. Obviously they also function individually.
And either they don't see us, or don't see us as a threat.
Transporter room, this is the Captain.
O'Brien here Captain.
If your lock on the away team wavers in the slightest -- beam them back.
Count on it, Captain.
Captain -- this is incredible. I have just entered what appears to be the nursery.
Describe it.

From the looks of it the Borg are born as biological life form. Almost immediately after birth they begin getting artificial implants. They have apparently developed the technology to link artificial intelligence directly into a humanoid brain. Pretty astounding. Something else -- I haven't seen any females.
Commander.
What is it?
The ship appears to be regenerating.
Perhaps this explains why they have not taken notice of our presence. Their collective effort is directed at repairing their vessel.
Captain, the Borg are using their combined power to repair the ship.
Transporter Chief, beam the away team directly to the bridge.
Now, Mister Crusher -- engage.
Captain -- the Borg ship is in pursuit.
On screen.
Magnify.
Increase by ten to the third.
It's continuing to regenerate itself.
Let's see if we can outrun it. Lietenant La Forge, I want maximum warp for as long as you can hold it.
Yes, sir.
We are passing warp eight point five.
... warp nine.
Arm the photon torpedoes. Recommend we try to slow them down.
Agreed.
Torpedoes armed.
Fire.
What is it? Is there something the matter?
No. You can study the theory -- read the books -- analyze schematics... but nothing of it prepares you for this. I have just never see or felt anything so awesome.
Well let's see if we can't raise the level a few more knotches.
They had no effect.
Bridge, this is Engineering. We are at warp nine point six five.
The Borg ship is still gaining.
They will follow this ship until you exhaust your fuel. They will wear down your defenses. Then you will be theirs.
You're out of your league, Picard. You should have stayed where you belonged.
Captain's log supplemental. We are unable to maintain the gap between the Enterprise and the Borg ship.
We are at the design limit.
Agreed. Bridge this is Engineering.
Go ahead.
You've got all we can give you.
I understand, Lieutenant La Forge.
Captain -- the enemy vessel is firing on us.
There are no reports of any damage to the Enterprise.
The target was not the ship. The weapon was designed to drain the shields.
Shield effectiveness has been reduced twelve percent.
The Borg ship is closing.
They are firing again.
Shields have been reduced by forty one percent. Another hit and we will be defenseless.
They are wearing you down. Soon you will be helpless.
Arm the photon torpedoes.
Torpedoes armed.
Fire the photons.
The Borg ship was not damaged.

You can't outrun them. You can't destroy them. If you damage them, the essence of what they are remains -- they regenerate and keep coming... eventually you will weaken -- your reserves will be gone... they are relentless.
The Borg ship is firing.
We have again lost the shields.
Bridge -- we have lost the warp engines.

Now where's your smugness -- your arrogance? Do you still believe you are prepared for what awaits you? I tried to tell you but listening has never been one of your laudable attributes. It makes me quite happy to now say -- I told you so.
The Borg ship is re-establishing its tractor beam.
Lock on photon torpedoes.
Yes, sir.
Without our shields -- at this range there is a high degree of probability that a photon detonation could destroy the Enterprise.
